case_vignette: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain in his right eye. The patient states that his eye hurts and that he cannot see well. He cannot remember when his symptoms started or what caused them. The patient has a past medical history of schizophrenia and IV drug abuse. His current medications include intramuscular haloperidol and nicotine patches. The patient has a 20 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 120/68 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, you note a poorly kempt man and the findings in Figure A. Pain is elicited upon examination of cranial nerve III in the right eye. The patient is unable to read a chart on the wall of the exam room and complains of double vision.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

My right eye hurts, I can't see well out of it, and I'm seeing double.
Have you had any of these symptoms before?
I can't remember when my symptoms started or what caused them.
Have you had any recent head injuries or surgeries?
I can't remember.
Have you been taking any medications recently?
Yes, I'm on intramuscular haloperidol and nicotine patches.
Have you had any changes in your vision or eye health in the past?
I can't remember any changes before this.
Have you had any family history of eye conditions or neurological disorders?
I don't know about my family history.
Have you had any other symptoms such as dizziness, nausea, or difficulty speaking?
No, I haven't mentioned any other symptoms like those.
Final Diagnosis: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
